abstracts.cdata!:
This environmental assessment (EA) of
            the Copperbelt Environment Project presents an evaluation of
            mining hazards in the Copperbelt and Kabwe from a risk-based
            perspective. The primary environmental health issue in the
            Copperbelt mining sector is exposure to sulfur dioxide and
            particulate emissions in Mufulira, Kitwe, and Chambishi.
            Copper is found in excessive quantities downstream from mine
            sites. In Kabwe lead contamination in soil presents an
            immediate health concern. This EA provides the following
            recommendations: a) Clear definitions of responsibilities
            need to be set among the different institutions involved. b)
            ZCCM-IH (an investment holding company), private sector mine
            operators, and regulatory authorities will need to form a
            consensus regarding priority environmental issues to be
            addressed by their respective site-specific environmental
            management plans. c) Expenditures of the Environmental
            Mitigation Fund (EMF) should be focused towards priority
            impacts as identified in this EA. d) The various
            institutions involved have basic mandates and technical
            competency, but require an organizational focus and training
            to enable them to adequately discharge their functions. e)
            The EMF will be required to establish procedures for
            screening, implementing EA, preparing resettlement action
            plans, and consulting with affected publics and NGOs and
            disclosing safeguard documents.
